[dismissive] Young man, I've lived behind this levee for forty years and every time, [annoyed], there's a little rain you people come knocking with your, [bitter], doomsday predictions.
[desperate] This isn't just rain, um, I mean we're talking about a fifteen-foot storm surge and, well, [breaking], the soil is already liquefying. [voice cracks]

[stubborn] Well, um, my Harold built this house with his bare hands in 1963 and, uh, [defensive], it's survived every hurricane since then so I'm not, [trembling], leaving everything we built together, you know, not for some numbers on your clipboard. [exhales]
[pleading] Please understand.

You know, um, everyone keeps telling me to leave but, well, [softer], where am I supposed to go when this house has every memory of him, [choking up], every photograph, every piece of furniture we picked out together? [long pause]
[gentle] Ma'am, I know this is hard but, um, Harold wouldn't want you to, well, [firm], stay here when the water's coming, and I mean, he'd want you safe. [sighs]
[wavering] The levee has always, [uncertain], held before.
[frantic] It's not holding now, I mean, um, I can literally hear the concrete cracking and, well, [terrified], we have maybe thirty minutes before total structural collapse.
[frightened] But, um, all my photo albums are upstairs and, well, I can't just, [breaking down], leave them to drown.
[compassionate] I'll help you grab what we can but we need to, [urgent], move right now because the water is already pooling at, [anxious], the base of your street. [determined]
The ground is making these, [scared], strange groaning sounds like something underground is, [whispered], shifting and moving. [shivers]
[steady] That's the hydrostatic pressure building, um, and when it releases, well, [grave], everything within a quarter mile will be under twenty feet of water.
Um, I suppose Harold always said I was too stubborn for my own good and, uh, [resigned], maybe he'd forgive me for saving myself instead of, well, [tearful], trying to save a house.
[relieved] Let me carry that box while you grab, um, [rushing], whatever else you absolutely need. [exhales deeply]
[shaking] I can hear it now, um, the water sounds different, like it's, well, [terrified], angry or hungry.
[grim] That's because it's already breached the secondary barrier and once it finds, [tense], the weak points in the primary wall. [trails off]
[accepting] Well, um, I guess forty years was a good run and, uh, [sad], maybe it's time to let go.
[kind] You're not letting go of the memories, just, [gentle], the physical structure that held them. [reassuring]

[resolved] Alright then, um, help me with Harold's urn from the mantle and, well, [determined], let's get out of here before this old levee finally decides to, [darkly humorous], retire after all these years. [hollow laugh]
